reviewText: So, I bought this book a few days ago and have tried three recipes so far.  The first was a total flop.  There must be an error, but be forewarned, do NOT make the Blueberry Coffee Cake as it comes out as inedible mush--WAY too much water.  The other two recipes (mac and cheese and grilled cheese with tomato) were decent for quick lunches or dinners.  They were average in taste, but considering the short amount of time it took to make them, I'm okay with that.  All in all, it's a nice idea book to get creative with everyday ingredients, but with errors and only average taste, I give it three stars.

The pros:1. It really teaches you the basics on cooking2. Really easy to make3. The recipes are categorized which make it easy to findThe cons:1. Some recipes are really high in calories2. Don't seem all that cheap to me, speaking from a college student on a budget
got it in good time. i think its a great book but i do wish there was more variety of things like desserts and breakfast options you can make fast

I bought this for my friend's birthday,and she absolutely loves it. This book is especially for beginners with easy to make recipes for breakfast,lunch and dinner. In the beginning it gives an intro on spices and different utensils which is extremely helpful. I'm even considering buying this myself. This book is absolutely adorable.
This is a good basic cookbook for new cooks and college students on their own for the first time.  My daughter is using it and reports good luck with the recipes.
summary: Healthy food choices for college students

reviewText: I bought this book for my friend's daughter who was going to college and wanted some recipes.  As I looked through the book, I loved the recipes so much, I ended up buying another book for myself.  Jessie, the college student, told me she has already used the book and was thrilled the food she made tasted fantastic and was easy to make.  Good and easy recipes.

As someone that is single and knows my way around the kitchen pretty well, I found this cookbook to be very useful for single people. A lot of recipes/cookbooks out there are geared towards families. It's hard to find recipes that are single serve. Some of my favorite recipes included steamed cabbage, simple green beans, beef stir fry.

After several days of hunting for the right book for a male college student, who doesn't cook, and lives with 5 other guys in a condo/dorm with a spectacular kitchen.........I chose this one because it is easy to use, there are few ingredients, it is basic (like making quesadillas), and things actually sound delicious.  Hope it is utilized but a mother  is the last one to know.

I absolutely love it! Everything I've tried so far tastes delicious, and it's affordable! It's great for when I make recipes just for myself, or when I have some friends over. I highly recommend this book.
The book has a lot of good ideas, but I only cared for a few recipes. Some take awhile to make and if it's aimed at collge students, time is an issue.

I'm a 21 year old junior in college and I've been struggling for a long time with not eating out so much. This book has helped me tremendously in overcoming that bad habit. I love the breakfast and sides sections. Very informative. Would recommend to anyone who is faced with a kitchen/cooking on their own for the first time.

I purchased this title for a roommate and this has helped a great deal.This book is simple enough for beginners to understand but some of the techniques used might be too advanced for the average college student.

... and this book caught my eye in the supermarket because i have a granddaughter in her 1st year of college.  she shares a condo near campus with 3 other roommates and  this will probably become their 'kitchen bible'.  i don't want to give the book away now that i'm reading it, and will have to get a copy for myself.  [that's why i'm here on amazon.]  after 50+ years of cooking, i want QUICK and EASY as well as healthy.  i flag almost every page i open the book to because of a recipe i want to try.  who would have thought of spaghetti squash with butter and CINNAMON?  (pg 236)

bought the healthy college cookbook for my grandson.and he was happy to receive it! i scanned it myself,and found recipes easy to use ,especially for students who are pressed for time-good healthy alternatives to a high fat fast food diet,so many young people follow-thanks for writing such a great book!

On his first summer away from home, my son used this book as his first. He liked the general cooking information in the book and used many recipes. Mostly he cooked a big batch of things and ate leftovers for the week. He particularly liked the Minestrone.
summary: My son found it very useful and made a number of recipes

reviewText: Great basic receipes. The only thing that would make it perfect is pictures. I bought it for my son in college and he is looking forward to cooking on his own.
summary: Good start for the college student

reviewText: I got this book for both of my daughters as they are just getting appartments for their new school year.They just started using some of the recipes in this book to practice on us at home.We like the recipe choices. This is a book that they will use at college.
There are a lot of quick and easy recipes in the book that nearly any college student could make. They all seem pretty healthy, too.

Our teenage daughter was looking for a healthy cookbook.  She is not a fan of cooking, so it had to be easy.  In just a month, she has made several recipes from the book - and they are easy and good!  Some things are overly simple (liked baked potatoes), but there are a lot of recipes.  Orange chicken is already a favorite.  We have enjoyed the 'Mom says' comments, and some of the comments from the college kids that wrote it.  I will have to get a copy for myself when she goes away to college!
After receiving this as a Christmas gift, my collegiate son looked at it and then left it home.  Maybe next year, when he moves out of the dorm...

Toss the Ramen Noodles and Indulge!I actually bought this book as a gift for a friend who was both getting married AND going to graduate school all in the same year. I put it together with a gift basket...She has no cooking experience.And she said it has been one of her most used gifts!That said, upon leafing through her own copy, I bought a second book...for myself...in spite of the fact that I love to cook and have been doing so for MANY years. The recipes are quick, delicious, imaginative, and (a great thing in this economy) inexpensive too!It's a very thorough book even for someone who only wants to own ONE cookbook. Ever.There are loads of recipes and varied tastes within...from fish, to beef, to chicken, even vegetarian and vegan recipes are included...even for those who aren't vegetarians those recipes are GOOD hearty ones that cross-over well to carnivores.  It just has a huge variety of bites.The recipes are diverse. Lots of good hearty American fare, but intermingled with Chinese, Indian, and Italian recipes. Also, there's everything from appetizers to breakfasts to salads to sandwiches to main dishes and desserts.I found the ingredients to be ones that could easily be found and the recipes to be simple enough for the beginner cook...and fast for those on the go who still like good food.there are even some great recipes to help throughout life...such as how to make croutons!We've enjoyed the huevos rancheros. blueberry coffee cake, breakfast burritos and orange french toast for breakfast.You can't lose with the fettucine alfredo, chicken and mushrooms, chicken fiesta salad, honey dijon salmon, lasagna, mexican lasagna, slow cooked barbecue chicken, chicken soup (lots of good soups and stews  And soy meats are easy substitutes here if you wish!and the chocolate souffle and apple cobbler are great endings!While it is great for a college student learning to cook and short on time and money, I think any cook who loves good food can benefit. Lots of healthy dishes and hearty meals for anyone..and for those who want the basics, there is even help knowing what basic kitchen tools are.
summary: This book is a winner for a cooking novice to a genuine foodie!

reviewText: I LOVE this cookbook. It's easy to use and has wonderful recipes in it. The main aspect I like most is the fact that it doesn't use unusual ingredients, usually they are easy to find. Definitely recommend.

My grand daughter in college had essentially never cooked before she left home.  She had no idea how to get around a kitchen, much less do it safely.  She loves the tips on cooking--what the terms mean (braise, blanch, etc.) and how to make substitutions if she doesn't have a certain ingredient on hand.  The recipes are easy to follow and healthy.
I find that there are not any complicated recipes or anything I had not made before. It is more used to get me out of my rut of cooking the same thing every night.

There are a few recipes that maybe your average college student wouldn't have time or ingredients for, but it really is a great starter book. Yes, it has no pictures, but it allows more room for recipes. Some of them literally take a few minutes like the peanut butter oatmeal one. Its so simple, but a wonderful quick idea. Sometimes its just nice to have an easy meal that isn't processed junk. It has recipes for everyone from your meat lovers to your vegans. It is fairly basic, but that is what most college students are looking for and need. This baby is getting me through nursing school and those long nights of studying. I don't know how I would have eaten without this darling book. It even has easy symbols indicating if they are vegan, vegetarian, quick, etc.
summary: Great for a busy college student

reviewText: Many health and delicious meals for our family that is easy to prepare. Economical on the  pocket book also. Saved us a lot on the budget

We were given this cookbook as a wedding gift.  We were a little skeptical but figured we'd give it a try, and it has become our go-to recipe book for quick, easy dinners after a long workday. While some recipes include 1-2 ingredients that may not be familiar, the recipes are typically healthy, easy to follow and don't require a lot of time or effort.  This is a great cookbook whether you are in college or not!
My granddaughter is into healthy cooking and eating.  She was glad to receive this book as the recopies seemed quick and easy.

I absolutely LOVE  this cookbook. It will be very helpful when I am at college. It is so easy to read, and great for beginner cooks like myself. It really is a healthy cookbook. It gives you all of the nutritional facts and really helps you make healthy decisions. The recipes are also take into consideration that you don't have a lot of time to prepare meals. I am so happy that I purchased this book. It makes me excited to cook!!

His senior year in high school he decided to eat healthier and lost about 50 pounds.  To help keep him healthy in college we got him this book - it seems to have great recipes that are quick and easy to make while staying within college budget constraints.

It is what it is.  For that, it gets four stars.  Don't expect anything mind-blowing but do expect the recipes in here to be totally doable for a novice.  It is full of easy-to-make, simple dishes that can help a newer cook make decent meals and improve as he or she becomes more comfortable in the kitchen.Some favorites: honey dijon salmon, apple chicken with mushrooms, sweet orange chickenI was not at all a fan of the lime-garlic shrimp and the baked tunaIf you are looking to save money, learn to cook and eat a little healthier, buy this book.  It has made learning to cook much easier via practice with simple, solid recipes and the fact that it is all in one place instead of spread out among various internet bookmarks.

I really like this cookbook a lot.  Everything is easy to do and I haven't had trouble finding the ingredients in the grocery store.  There are lots of things to make and I especially like that the book tells you if you can make it in a hurry and if it's a favorite among the college students.  I'm glad I bought it.
Perfect for a college student, especially one that lives in a dorm and has access to a kitchen or simple hot plate cooking.
i recommend this cookbook becase it has good tips about how keep your kicthen.it has good recipes and some tips you want to make sure you do when handling meat.

I bought this book because it had received decent reviews and being a household of 1; I had hoped that I could make some quick meals.I am not a experienced chef by any means but don't consider myself a true beginner. I know how to make some basics and figured this may give me some fresh ideas.It seemed the ideas were TOO basic. And they didn't seem to have any fresh outlook on recipes.I wish I had invested in something I would read and use more often.

I've just finished up my sophomore year of college and this cookbook has been a hit in my apartment. The front section is helpful for beginner cooks who don't know the difference between parsley and oregano, as well as conversions and instructions on how to mince, dice, etc. The only drawback to this book that I can think of is that there are no pictures of the final product. Other than that, it's a simple, practical cookbook that I'm sure I'll use for years.
summary: Most everything a college student would need to know in the kitchen

reviewText: I bought this for both of my college kids and they loved it!  They didn't know what they needed in terms of food and spices to start up their kitchen.  It is great to see fast and healthy foods to make.

I have been looking for a cookbook like this for some time.  I am a grad student without much time or money.  This book had some helpful idea for foods that I need to keep in my kitchen, and some simple recipes.  The trouble with being a student is that it is very easy to fall into the habit of just grabbing fast food on a regular basis, but that will end up costing you more in the end: money and health.  The down side of this book is that there are no pictures, and some of the recipes are actually quite complex.  I was also hoping for more easy crock pot meals.  While not perfect, I found this book to pretty helpful for a single graduate student with very little time and on a tight budget.
not too good, needs more recipes. very disappointing. wouldn't recommend . other cook books available that would be much  better.
this book has saved me this past year while budgeting and trying to stay healthy a great buy for parents who have kids going to college

This book is AWESOME!!!!!!!!!! I don't even know where to start! is it because of the delicious amazing recipes? or maybe the countless tricks and tips throughout the whole thing, or maybe the whole Getting started guide at the front of the book? I really don't know what is the most awesome part about it, but needless to say I am IN LOVE with this book!!!!
Plenty of great, easy recipes that take very little time.  The book also makes sure the cook knows exactly how to cook each recipe.
summary: A Great Book for the Hard at Work College Student

reviewText: I've purchased this cookbook for all of my children -- they love the recipes.  It's a great way to introduce healthy cooking to your kids, who of course don't want to spend a lot of time in the kitchen while at school!

as a college student, this book was amazing for me to start out with. easy, quick recipes that are great for leftovers during class or after a long day. i don't know what i did before this book came into my life.

Maybe its just bad luck.. but the first two recipes i try turned out awful... there seem to be issues with the amounts of ingredients.. for a cream sauce..it told me to use 1.5 CUPS of flowers with 1.25 cups of milk... i guess i shouldn't have blindly followed the recipes.. so it was a big waste of time and ingredients.. and it came out with a big floury goo mess...most of the recipes seem pretty basic. it would be a good tool for learning i don't continue to find typos..
I would recommend the product. It is interesting and shipped really fast, which was nice since it was a gift.
Recipes are simple/ just the type I was looking for. Some of the simpler dishes are more like snacks though which was not as good. Otherwise, I loved it!

These recipes are easy and cost effective.  There's a section that even explains what all the cooking terms mean: minced, diced, poached, chopped, etc.  I bought this for a recent grad about to move out and she loved it.
bought this for my nephew when he started college. He has an apartment he shares with three other guys and I thought he could use it to start learning to cook for himself.
My cookbook was in great condition and came quickly. I have used it a few times and loved most of the things I tried. I would definitely recommend this book and seller to anyone.

this cook book was extremely basic. It seems to be made for someone who has no idea what to do in a kitchen. So i you don't know how to hard boil and egg then this book would be really helpful. however, I had hoped for more complex recipes. I do like how the recipes have calorie counts.
I'm only 17, this cookbook helped my no-skill cooking to seem like a 5 star chef!!!!!!!!!! Yummy I wish they made another one!

I got this as a present for my sister who is in college and loves to cook. All I can say it..WOW! I thought it would be nice of me to kind of thumb through and bookmark a few she might like to try....after looking at every single recipe I ended up with over 30 bookmarks for me alone! I don't enjoy cooking at all but the recipes all looked to easy and quick, I thought even I would try them. I would recommend this cookbook to anybody, even if you aren't in college.
I LOVE using this book to start learning how to cook, There are simple and easy ideas in here and the book arrived in excellent condition!

I am an older student, but I still found myself falling victim to the typical poor eating habit of fast food or take out all the time.  That is the sentiment with most of my classmates, including other adults my age and older.  This book has a lot of easy common sense recipes, and some really great different ideas.  I honestly have yet to cook anything from it, but I did read it cover to cover.  The beginning is full of valuable information about the basics of cooking that everyone should know, as people are cooking less and eating out more.  Everything is simple to make and contains whole ingredients for the most part.I gave it 4 stars because there were a few recipes in there that are not so healthy as far as calorie and fat content.  I recall seeing something that had about 1000 calories a serving, that's TOO much for a "healthy" meal.  The book talks about spices and herbs in the beginning, but it also focuses on saving money since college students are typically on a limited budget.  I think it would have been cute if it had incorporated growing your own herbs.  It's simple, money saving, and can be done indoors with little space.  I still cannot believe how much they charge for a few sprigs of Rosemary or Basil at the grocery store!
summary: Great for people of all ages

reviewText: When I went away to College finding things that are simple to make wasn't as easy as it would seem, especially when your trying to be healthy! This book offers a lot more options for me now, and I absolutely love the lists of basics to have on hand. Stocking my pantry for the first time was tough and these lists helped a lot!

I've been out of college for several years now, but I still go back to this cookbook for many recipes. The sweet potato fries, honey and garlic chicken, and orange chicken are all family favorites. This cookbook was definitely easy to use while in school because the recipes didn't require tons of obscure ingredients that were only used in one recipe; if an out of the way ingredient WAS called for, it was repeated in several recipes. That meant fewer trips to the local grocery store. I love this cookbook and it will stay on my shelves for a long time (and I'm a dedicated foodie who is choosy about what cookbooks I use).

This seems like a great cookbook for someone starting out on their own for the first time & not having much cooking knowledge.  So I got it as a gift for a family member who's a freshman in college.  Not sure what she thinks of it as I haven't heard anything.

Bought this for my daughter who's in college and getting her first apartment.  Nice recipes, good layout.  Lots of handy information for setting up a college apartment kitchen.  Nice cheerful illustrations too.

I'm a college student who struggles with money and eating healthy as a resultI'm already a good cook, but when i saw this at the library i work at: i knew i had to have itThis book is wonderful, so many good ides that i'm eager to try :)

I originally purchased his book for my niece and she is maybe using it occassionally. I still thought it was a great cookbook and I bought another one for my son when he started his second year of college and was to start cooking. This time it was received with great appreciation and is being used regularly. It is the only cookbook they own and the 4 boys rely on it for their evening meals.

This book was perfect!  I bought this for my daughter who was heading off to her first apt. and graduate school.  The lists for setting up her kitchen were very helpful--pots and pans, cooking utensils, fridge basics, pantry items, spices, etc. She also found lots of recipes that she marked to try.

I bought this for a friend whose daughter is leaving for college soon.  She's been complaining she's going to starve because she doesn't know how to cook. After reviewing it, I decided not to give it to her.  I think most of the recipes are just too complicated for the typical college student, and some of the ingredients are not easily found in a small college town.  I'll keep searching for another one.
summary: Recipies a bit complicated for college kids

reviewText: My son loves to cook and he thinks this book is great!  Lots of healthy choices that are delicious and easy to make as well!  I would definitely recommend this to young cooks and older ones, too.

This book is awesome. It just proves that eating healthy doesn't have to cost tons of money and tons of time! The recipes use normal ingredients that people would have cooked with 100 years ago. These recipes are not fancy and are not a lot of things that you have never heard of so if you are looking for something to try obscure recipes this is not it. If you ARE looking for something straight forward with good, solid healthy recipes that taste delicious and will help keep on your budget BUY THIS BOOK! I've been out of college for almost 10 years and I have 3 kids and a husband to feed and we all love these recipes! I wish I would have had it in college too...it's really a great book for anyone!
summary: Just what I thought didn't exist...but here it is!

reviewText: Good recipes, and my nineteen year-old son is anxious to cook in college now!  It would have been nice to have photos of the entrees though.

I got this book for both my nephew & niece when they started college. It's great for the beginning cook and all the ingredients are easy to find at any grocery. Even my nephew who was a "throw it in the micro" kid, made things out of it!

I highly recommend this book. It has two lists of basics foods you should have, one for the fridge and one for the cupboard. The recipes actually use the stuff on the list! Every now and then you'll want to add something like fruits, veggies and meat to your shopping list but they are all easy to find ingredients. LOVE!
summary: One of the best cookbooks you could get for college!

reviewText: I really like the way that this book is organized and the way that it explains everything. I'm new to cooking and this book simplifies recipes when it can and explains where it can't. This is a must have for any college student who didn't do much cooking in the past.
I am no longer in college, but this is still one of my favorite go-to cookbooks. All of the recipes I have tried are very quick and easy to make, and are delicious!

Great for all of the college students in your life who you cringe watching them try to live off Ramon noodles - yuck!  My son and his girlfriend use this book regularly to fit healthy more well-balanced meals into their days. I am so glad I bought this. They come for dinner much less now and that is a bummer but at least I know they are taking care of themselves amidst their super busy lives.
summary: If you want them to eat right at their own dorm/apt. this is a must buy and gift it book

reviewText: Plenty of variety, easy to make, and super inexpensive! I'd recommend this book to any college student living in an apartment.
This cook book got me on track to cooking for myself. It has a lot of healthy recipes that are also delicious. This book will help you save money and teach you to cook.

The book has a big variety of recipes. It has recipes for vegans and for the ultimate meat lovers. It provides basic knowledge for the kitchen and how to cook. The recipes for the most part are cheap and delectable.

This book has been used many times by me in the last few months and I love it. My favorite recipe in it so far was a meat chili. My roommates said it was the best chili ever. I'm not really a gourmet person so this cookbook is perfect. I don't want a ingredient list that takes an hour at the supermarket to fill. Most of the recipes in this book are quick and easy to make. Whenever a recipe didn't turn out, I found it to me my fault since I'm not a great cook. I'm really happy with this purchase and it's worth every penny. There's something for everyone in this book.
Has great info for the beginner, but would like some photos to help see what it looks like. Recommended for sure
summary: Great recipe selection..but wish it had more pictures

reviewText: Great cookbook. I use it all of the time. There are lots of selections sure to please just about anyone. I've even had friends and family copy recipes for themselves. My sisters starting college and I'm going to order one for her too!

I am not a big cook so I was looking for a cookbook with easy, healthy and affordable recipes. I was pleasantly surprisrd when going through this book there were many choices my husband and I would like. Great book!
summary: just what i was looking for

reviewText: Even though I have been out of college for several years I ordered this cookbook through my Kindle thinking it would be perfect since I live alone and do not always feel like cooking a lot for myself.  When I ordered it, I imagined the recipes would be creative healthy snacks one could cook in a non-stocked kitchen, since it is described as a dorm room cookbook.  I found the recipes to be very very basic and require too many pots, pans, and utensils.  I cannot imagine any dorm or college kitchen being so well stocked.  I am not impressed and it was not what I was looking for.

Some of these recipes are just outstandingly creative. Every recipe is straightforward, simple, and EVEN highly practical.Here's an example of the book's practicality:  For one of the recipes ("Pita Pizza"), directions include the suggestion to consider making this recipe after chopping vegetables for your prior meal, to use as toppings!) Now I don't know about anybody else, but since I'm as clueless as I am about cooking right now, I sure find tips like this useful in the learning the thinking process of a cook!
summary: Outstandingly Creative & Practical Guide For the Newbie

reviewText: I really couldn't wait to get this book so I could begin to learn how to cook meals. The book shows a lot of things to beginner cooks like me such as: which spices are good for which food and what is def needed in your apartment. Thanks to this book I really have enjoyed cooking! I recommend it for beginners. Even though there aren't any photos, I just used my imagination

I received this book as a gift and since I love cooking, I immediately began using recipes from it. BIG mistake. This is one of the worst cookbooks I have ever used. First, it assumes that college students eat tiny portions; for example, the chili recipe is listed as "serves 6" but it was barely enough food for me and two friends. Also, several of the recipes turned out terribly despite my efforts to follow the instructions exactly. Tiny portions and absurd instructions make this a terrible cookbook for college students or anyone. NOT recommended.
It has tons of great recipes and all kinds of helpful cooking tips for the average college kid.  Great gift for the college kid on your list!
summary: Awesome cook book for an awesome price!

reviewText: Bought  2 of these cook books for my grandsons that are in college.  Much to my surprise they are using them.

Someone sent me this book because I was going back to college and meal prep time was at a premium. This book turned out to also make cooking actually... fun?! The recipes contain few but well thought out ingredients, and the prep is fast! Seriously, before you know it you are stuffing it in the oven. The food is good and nutritious, with inexpensive fresh ingredients. I'm 50, and painlessly losing weight!I will be buying another one for my daughter when she heads off to college, because I'm keeping this one.
summary: Great for busy people and empty nesters

reviewText: Overall, I really like this book. I've been able to try about 15 different recipes. Only one of them I didn't like (but that was my fault!). I knocked it down one star because, well, some of these are really complex. I feel like the majority of college students don't have a few hours to sit around cooking in the evening.With that in mind, the vast majority of the recipes are quick and easy ways to eat yummy food that is healthy for you. A great guide for anyone trying to avoid that Freshman 15.

Slick car adapter that can be used for multiple devices.Solid design and good looks with simple green LED to indicate power.  I like the brilliant space saving side cord design.  Makes the adapter more compact and less likely to tangle with a stick shift.  Makes you wonder why somebody didn't do this sooner and why 99% of the adapters out there still have that annoying cord end that adds inches to the adapter and tangles with the shifter/cupholder/etc.  Tips for nearly every device out there.BUT, the only the BLUE tips are compatible with the iGo Wall adapter.  DO NOT BUY THE GREEN TIPS. I'd like to meet the bean counter that made that decision...  Otherwise, I'd give it 5 stars.  I guess they want to make more money on the @#*%$ tips.
summary: One car adapter for all your toys- BUT BUY ONLY BLUE TIPS

reviewText: I'm a little confused with the description of this item. They imply that it delivers differing output voltages for various appliances you want to power, but nowhere do they actually state this outright. It works fine for my Kyocera phone. But will it also work for a nine-volt radio or a three-volt set of noise-reduction headphones? If I find out that it does, I'll change my four stars to five.
summary: Works for my phone, but what about devices with differing voltage?

reviewText: My father bought this as a suggested add-on to the Amazon Kindle - and I suspect a lot of other customers but this product the same sort of way. What they don't tell you is that you need to buy two things - the power adapter AND an "iGo Power Tip for Amazon Kindle". With the extra cost ($12) we felt we were both deceived and cheated. Particularly because the picture for the iGo Autopower power adapter includes a picture of the Power Tip (not actually included). But we were determined to make it all work and after an extra trip to an electronics store it now does. Overall I was impressed by the product but beware of what you are really getting.
summary: Works well but a little deceptive

reviewText: When I found myself with a depleted cell phone several hours into a twelve hour drive, with nothing but an AC charger stowed in a suitcase, I stopped at the first electronics store I could find to buy a charger.Without hesitation, I purchased the iGo Autopower 3000, along with two tips, one for my Motorola V300 and one for my father's Sprint PCS phone.The IGO AutoPower 3000 is basically a generic 12v adapter.  You plug in your device-specific interchangeable tip to charge your electronics device.  In my case, it was a cell phone.We used both during the trip to charge our phones without any problems.Simple, reliable, and effective.  Recommended.

Reading this poetry was a whole new experience for me...and in the end a totally pleasant experience into the world of sexual play.  The book is divided into six sections.  I enjoyed some sections more than others.  Where the poems covered many different sexual partnerships and situations, I enjoyed them all with no reservations.As an avid reader, I found the rhythm of the words and the pictures they created very exciting.  Sometimes sentences in regular prose take too long to convey a thought, whereas poetry can use one word to describe an action, a thought or a feeling with such speed and power.The author’s praise and undeniable respect for the female body creates a very stimulating read.  It would be wonderful to believe that your lover would be aroused with just the simple act of watching you walk across a room.I recommend this book of poetry to all readers who have open minds to the exciting world of sensual pleasures.

I enjoy vintage books and movies so I enjoyed reading this book.  The plot was unusual.  Don't think killing someone in self-defense but leaving the scene and the body without notifying the police or hitting someone in the jaw to knock them out would wash today.Still it was a good read for me.

This book is a reissue of an old one; the author was born in 1910. It's of the era of, say, Nero Wolfe. The introduction was quite interesting, explaining who the author was and why he's been forgotten; I'd never heard of him.The language is a little dated at times, like calling a gun a "heater."  I also made good use of my Fire's dictionary to look up words like "deshabille" and "Canarsie." Still, it was well worth a look-see.
Really good story although Amy Brewster does not really figure much other than being in the story.  The lead character certainly does figure in the story and its hard action from the get go.
summary: Really good story although Amy Brewster does not really figure much ...

reviewText: This was a fairly interesting read.  It had old- style terminology.I was glad to get  to read a story that doesn't have coarse, crasslanguage.  I read for fun and relaxation......I like the free ebooksbecause I can check out a writer and decide if they are intriguing,innovative, and have enough of the command of Englishthat they can convey the story without crude language.
I'd never read any of the Amy Brewster mysteries until this one..  So I am really hooked on them now.
If you like period pieces - clothing, lingo, you will enjoy this mystery.  Author had me guessing at least 2/3 of the way through.

This book almost demands the time to read it straight through. The kind you read curled up on a sofa with hot chocolate by your side. A wonderful evenings entertainment. Would like more from this author with some of same characters.
A beautiful in-depth character description makes it like a fast pacing movie. It is a pity Mr Merwin did not write 30 instead only 3 of the Amy Brewster mysteries.
I enjoyed this one tho I'm not sure why it's called An Amy Brewster Mystery as she's not in it very much. It was clean, well written and the characters well drawn.

Never heard of Amy Brewster. But I don't need to like Amy Brewster to like this book. Actually, Amy Brewster is a side kick in this story, who added mystery to the story not the one resolved it. The story brings back the old times, simple life, simple people and straight relationships.

reviewText: GEORGE F WORTS = ERLE STANLEY GARDNER = GILLIAN HAZELTINE = PERRY MASON = COURTROOM LAWYER DRAMA = MURDER MYSTERY = 1930s PERIOD AUTHENTICITY = GREAT FUN
This book does little to shed any new light on Ed Wood.The author makes several claims she cannot back up and extrapolates others through circuitous logic.Best avoided.
summary: Not worth the time to download

reviewText: A collection of the first three Interplanetary Huntress adventures.Hothouse PlanetDual WorldSatellite FiveWhen Gerry Carlyle goes to Venus on a hunt, Tommy Strike ends up going with her. She is no-nonsense, used to being in charge and being the boss.However, Tommy knows more than a thing or two about interplanetary wildlife himself, some of which Gerry doesn't. That, and different operating methodology causes some friction.3.5 out of 5"That man of mine," said Gerry Carlyle. "He's gotten himself into a jam, I fear."He has done, too. Tommy has gone to do a bit of exploring of the Venusian Lost Continent, ignoring some normal procedure, and looking to make some money on the side.His ideas for getting themselves out of the situation aren't instilling too much confidence in Gerry's aide that is unlucky enough to be stuck with him.Luckily, the Huntress herself is on the ball, and he deserves the abuse he gets.3.5 out of 5Tommy is none too happy that the paralysis ray Gerry wants used on the monster laying waste to those that go to Satellite Five is tested on him!Off he goes, nonetheless. Gerry then finds out some information, and she is not averse to a bit of the old phone book and fall down the stairs type of police work to get it.Hooking up with a hotshot French pilot, she is off to Satellite Five.Tommy is holding his own, but she fails to believe that as well as asexual production, the creature adapts to weapons used against it in previous generations.3.5 out of 5

Good stuff. well written. Gerry is a heroine worth cheering for. She's strong, brave and confident, a perfect antidote to the weak female tabula rasas in novels today---I'm looking at you, "Twilight".

The most important lesson I learned as a student pilot long ago was the concept of being "pilot in command". If you're in the left seat and off the ground, you're responsible for the lives of everyone on board. The pilot of a Cessna 150 has to realize that he has just as much authority as the captain of a 777.This book reinforces the rights and responsibilities each pilot must understand.Pilot in CommandAs the King school motto goes:Takeoffs are optional.Landings are mandatory.
summary: Great for new pilots, and old buzzards too..

reviewText: Technically, this book is supposed to be preparation for shelf exams for 3rd year med students, but I used this as a source of questions when studying for the Preventive Medicine Board certification exam (post internal medicine/preventive medicine residency). As others preparing for the exam might have found, there's very little in the way of a good question bank.At first, I didn't think it would be useful to go through these given how outdated the book is - however, it was recommended to me by others who took (and passed) the exam in the past.I found that it's actually a pretty good source of questions - epidemiology & biostats, after all, hasn't changed from 2000 and those questions were certainly useful. Some of the questions from the Preventive Medicine in-service exam come verbatim from this book. You'll have to update your answers related to USPSTF guidelines, of course.I did the entire book of questions before taking the ABPM exam. It's certainly not enough - you'll need a reference book or books as well. I used this in conjunction withMayo Clinic Preventive Medicine and Public Health Board Review (Mayo Clinic Scientific Press)andEpidemiology, Biostatistics and Preventive Medicine: With STUDENT CONSULT Online Access, 3e, mostly using the former. The questions on biostats, however, are pretty helpful for testing the concepts. They're definitely easier than the actual exam...Lack of a good question bank and reference source is a definite problem for Preventive Medicine Board Exam candidates. (I've written to the ABPM about it). BUT that said, I think this is the best thing out there as far as question prep.  I did pass the exam, thankfully!
summary: outdated, but good preparation for the ABPM exam

reviewText: An omnibus of Interplanetary Huntress adventures 4 and 5.The Energy EatersThe Seven SleepersA couple of blokes with a little problem on the moon with some beasties and their electrical abilities need the help of Gerry Carlyle, and try a little psychology to get her assistance.3 out of 5Some space walking around a comet, some chases and other hair rising situations for Gerry, Tommy and crew. All to do with the evil media, perhaps.3.5 out of 5

I'd read this book as a teenager when I came upon a dusty, very old copy in my local library. I decided to re-read it many years later because I remembered it as a fun adventure novel. I bought the Kindle version, which unfortunately has a lot of typos.  This story could make a great movie.
I enjoyed the short stories. Some I had read before. I wish it were longer. It is basically just a copy of magazine stories published long ago when Lamour was just getting started.

Good collection of pulp fiction stories from Louis's early years.  If you are a long standing fan and avid reader of HIS books as I am,you'll appreciate these stories,and will probably recognize some of them as the basis for some of his published works.  If you are just now starting to read his books, these collection of short stories will provide you with the ground work for most of his books. Just what you would expect from a fabulous writer - loved him as a kid, appreciate him even more as an adult!

NEED MORE LAMOR BOOKS AS EBOOKS. NEED MANY MORE TO ENJOY. EASY TO READ ON THE IPAD. MAKE THEM AVAILABLE SOON.

I love Louis L'Amour!  McQueen and the various characters are some of my favorites.  The stories are great westerns, but I have also found teachings about responsibility to the land, other people and spiritual lessons.  I have been reading his books since I was in high school forty five years ago.  They contain a lot more than shoot em ups. but if that is all you want, they are still wonderful.

Louis L'Amour is a writer I've enjoyed since my youth. Recently I asked my Facebook friends for book suggestions because I was in a rut. L'Amour came up and I dove back in. Pure entertainment without a single ulterior motive.
A typical L'Amour western, not one of his best but enjoyable nevertheless. L'Amour is always a good read, good excapeism.

This book was full of "lessons" that L'Amour wanted written; the lessons seemed forced and I didn't feel this was his best work.I bought this for the Kindle...sure do love that and the ability to buy and receive books right away. Wonderful stories that grab you immediately and pull you in to times, places and peoples lives. Concise, descriptive writing. Good flow and length.
In all my years of reading westerns there is none better than Louis L'amour.  This book like the rest is correct to the place and doesn't have to include foul language and sex.

reviewText: It is easy to under rate a writer of "Western Yarns". It was enjoyable to find a compilation of some of L'Amour's stories with a critical review and examples of the skill that L'Amour honed over a prodigious output/career. Some of his work may have been uneven but overall he managed his talent and business with grace, skill and audacity. His best work is an example of fine writing, period.

I have long been a fan of Louis L'Amour.  His characters are strong and well rounded.  His descriptive passages conjure up a picture in the mind.  Apart from being good old cowboy adventures, there is also a depth of character in the heroes and a message to never give up in the face of adversity.  I enjoy his short stories as much as his novels.

Louis L'Amour will always be the best wester writer of all time. This compilation of his work in articles and short stories show how the man who lived what he wrote exceled at putting you in the moment flawlessly.

bring back all those childhood dreams of being a cowboy, riding for the brand and saving the girl you were sweet on.

reviewText: Dermot Michael Coyne accompanies his wife Nuala Anne McGrail as she performs at the Celtic international music festival in Milan.  While in Italy, Dermot and Nuala Anne meet fellow Chicago resident Seamus Costelloe and his family.  After unceremoniously dumping Seamus into the pool for insulting his wife, Dermot and Nuala Anne agree to joining the Costelloe brood for dinner.  Nuala Anne noticed the mark of death on Seamus, a blowhard with many enemies not all in organized crime.Meanwhile the couples' daughter hears the explosion associated with the Windy City's Haymarket Riot.  The only problem is that the incident occurred over a century ago.  To provide solace to his daughter who believes that someone is crying for fairness through her, Dermot tries to uncover the truth over who really started the riot.  Meanwhile Nuala Anne, perhaps being the only person to see any good in Seamus, tries to keep him alive as she believes that is why her Irish fey powers gave her the sign.The latest Nuala Anne tale is a fun to read story because the two lead characters are a delight to watch in action even if she is a too perfect Irish goddess.  The dual story lines require leaps of faith as the audience will struggle with why Nuala Anne feels obligated to protect Seamus and why Dermot believes he must solve the Haymarket Riot mystery.  Still fans of Andrew M. Greeley's "Irish" series and those paranormal cozy readers who can forgive the chasm between the first and second dominos of the plot will dine on IRISH STEW.Harriet Klausner
summary: fun to read paranormal historical mystery

reviewText: Another good read in the Greeley series.  Nuala Anne is at her best again and I always enjoy her unique circumstances
I have read about everything he has written and enjoyed all but one earlier book. This was great. try it!

This is a review of the Kindle edition of the Oxford Dictionary of Idioms.  I have the Oxford Dictionary that comes preloaded on the Kindle and I love it because it has an active search, hyperlinks to other related words and a search-able list for words.  But the Kindle edition of the Oxford Dictionary of Idioms'  search does not work.  You click on "search" and nothing happens.  The Kindle has a search, but it isn't as convenient as the active book search, like the Kindle Oxford Dictionary.  The only other option I have is going page by page by hitting the Kindle's "next page" button.  But this book has 5000 idioms and one Kindle page for each.  I wasted $9.99.  You are better off getting the paperback or seeing about a better formatted kindle idiom dictionary made by another publisher.

Jean Marie Stine did something I've never seen done before. She found all the Do Nots an author must revise in order to insure a best selling manuscript. Her book revealed many subject I needed to address in my own writing. I highly recommend reviewing any writings, you wish to publish, against the information the author presents in this book.

This is not so much a book as an extended chapter of pithy what not to do's whenwriting a self help book.  They are good self help tips but she could have writtenmore about self publishing and how to promote books.  Writers who don't promote theirown books are destined to be one of 95% of writers who don't sell any more than1,000 books.  This book was mainly directed at writers who want to sell to main streampublishers through agents.What I liked best about it is that she suggested to write more than one book and gaveexamples of famous writers who did not sell a lot of books on their first book. Shecorrectly stated that a second third or fourth book builds sales for the first bookSadly most people who write books are the artsy types without a sales or businessbackground.  A mediocre book will always sell way better with constant promotion thana brilliant book with no promotion.  I also suggest that you join Toastmasters and learnthe art of public speaking.  If you can't master this or refuse you are also destined to fail.She also neglects to say that self help non fiction books sell better than  fictionbooks.If you really want to write a book that sells I suggest that you read several goodbooks about how to promote your book.  Writing the book is the easy part, the hardpart is in selling it.  If you don't have time to personally promote the book I suggestthat you don't bother.John Wilder is an award winning public speaker and is a marriage, relationship and sexualcoach with his own book coming out in January on Amazon on Kindle
summary: A good primer for first time writers

reviewText: I really like this book. It's easy to follow, has lots of great ideas and it helped me a lot with my writing.
summary: Fantastic book filled with lots of great ideas

reviewText: The book "how to write a bestselling self-help book" is helping to implement my goals. The book have given me a lot tips about books, proposal and other issues about how to write a book. It is useful tool. I'm writing three books (by children phases) for self-helping how to raise a child, because I know that we don't need to be a PHd to raise one.
summary: How to write a bestselling self-help book

reviewText: If you enjoy cozy mysteries then you'll enjoy this book. This was my first book by Camille Minichino, but it certainly won't be my last! I feel as though the characters are part of my family, and that Boston is as familiar as my own town.

When her fiancée died a few weeks before the wedding Gloria Lamerino packed her bags and moved to California where she taught physics at a major university for thirty years.  Upon her retirement, she moved back to her home in Revere, Massachusetts when she meets homicide detective Matt Gennara.  For the first time in three decades, she is in a serious relationship while also serving as a special science consultant to the police.Matt and Gloria are eating dinner at the home of her good friends Frank and Rose Galigani when the police suddenly show up to take the son John of their hosts in for questioning in the death of his ex-girlfriend, Angel Fiore.  Even though circumstantial evidence points to John as the murderer, Gloria knows he didn't do it and sets out to prove it with a little help from Matt.Camille Minchino is a dynamite writer showing readers that life including sex remains strong after fifty.  The heroine is gutsy and smart, as she is not afraid to find a killer among a plethora of suspects.  The plot is intricately woven with enough red herrings purposely placed into the story line to keep readers from guessing who the real killer is. The BORIC ACID MURDER is a who-done-it that keeps the reader's attention so they won't miss out on the real clues hidden in the overall tale.Harriet Klausner

I've read several of Camille Minichino's mysteries in her Periodic Table series and have enjoyed them all!It's interesting that a retired physicist writes a mystery novel with a retired physicist as the main character!As they say, write what you know.I've enjoyed her characters, Gloria, the detective who eventually becomes her husband, and her long friendship with Rose.The stories are nicely woven, and she manages to keep the reader in suspense till the end!
summary: Good read, and I learned some chemistry too!

reviewText: I had fun reading this mystery and found it easy to identify with Gloria. Gloria her fiance,her friends, and all the others became real people in this book. At times I was on the edge of my chair worried and other times I could feel the comfort her friends and her fiance gave each other with their support. It was a very good mystery and nothing like any others I have read. Very enjoyable.
summary: The Boric Acid Murderr, a Gloria Lamerino Mystery

reviewText: If you want to read a book about a woman's sexual fantasy land - this is for you. Personally, I didn't learn very much about anything else about sex except what might turn a woman's brain on. Also, there are no techniques or tools in this book. I let it go quickly after reading it.
summary: Bad Book, Unless You Wanna See A Woman's Brain On Sex

I have learned new things about financial control, household item usage, and purchase or sales of goods.  I gave a friend information about creating a job from home and he's doing okay so far. Good story but needs more sex. it was hot but it could be much hotter. not Robbins best work as far as I‘m concerned.

I read Harold Robbins years ago & decided to read some more titles by him.This was not a book that should have his name on.It does not hold your attention as his original work does.While I would probable read I would not classify this as something that has his name on it

Twenty-two years old Las Vegas waitress Betty Riordan receives her fifteen minutes of "fame" when an ancient Howard Hughes has sex with her.  Betty gives birth to a boy she names Howard Hughes, Jr.  Three months after that Betty with her infant in tow tries to visit the father of her child.  However, the Hughes entourage simply hands her cash to leave town with the renamed baby, Zack Riordan.Zack returns to Vegas at twelve where he thinks the Strip must be home to God.  He earns a minor living distributing sheets for the low life casinos.  However, when Betty, as he calls his mother, is killed, Zack leaves town.  He returns several years later and becomes a student of the gambling experts who know every cheating trick possible.  His advanced degree in cheating leads to his appointment as security manager at Vegas' Glitter Gulch until the owner's daughter Morgan fires him.  In retaliation he rapes her and flees to Asia before eventually returning to SIN CITY only to learn he sired a child with Morgan.Five years have passed since Harold Robbins died and he still is cranking out tales as a prolific ghostwriter.  The latest Robbins tale, SIN CITY, is perhaps "his" best novel in many years including when the author lived.  Sort of written as a biographical fiction, the reader sees Las Vegas as a siren of the desert luring wannabes and cheats to its glittery idols.  Fans of the author and his living retinue will enjoy SIN CITY by far the best of the posthumous career.Harriet Klausner
Great read.  Good charactors. Reminds me of the early books he wrote but in more of a modern setting.  Would like to see more of his unpublished matl. make it to print

The story is familiar.  We root for the street-smart hero, who we learn early on is the illegitimate son of Howard Hughes.  The kid grows up tough with the grit and guts to confront power brokers and move up the ladder of high living.  Explicit bedroom scenes pepper the fast-moving narrative.  And the bad things our hero does are only for well-deserved revenge.  The true stories that legends are made of, such as Bugsy Siegel and the Flamingo, give the tale a ring of authenticity.  When there's lots money around, there's also lots of cheating, and I was fascinated by the many scams and cons from slot machines to high-stakes Baccarat.  The constant tension drove the plot, cumulating in a card game in the finale that had me holding my breath.The book's 383 pages are easy reading and I gulped it down in two sittings.  I found it a pleasure to just relax and follow the story.  No deep thinking is required.  And I didn't learn anything new.  It was just pure pleasure.  Which is what reading for entertainment is all about.
summary: Gangsters.  Gambling.  Las Vegas.  Violence.  I loved it!

reviewText: ...there's no escape until the last page.  SC really delivers, and in my opinion is the best of HRs posthumas novels.  Would love to see this as a movie.
An interesting read that was hard to set aside.  It kept the story line moving and held my attention. The story was fast paced and I enjoyed it.
i likie all of harold robbins books sometimes it gets a little exsplicey but other parts r good. i hope to see more books by him.

There is no way to contact Amazon books and talk to someone as I cannot find a phone number nor a place to write.....I am very frustrated.

I bought this book after reading Robbins' 79 Park Avenue, which I highly recommend. This book didn't really do it for me. The best parts of the story are the real-life Vegas mafia history and the explanations of different ways people scam and cheat the casinos. The "love" stories and everything else that didn't involve money, gambling, intrigue, or international crime were just lame and felt tacked-on. The main thing I didn't like was the casual attitude toward rape that made the novel feel extremely mysoginistic despite some sympathetic female characters. Still I must admit, this is a suspenseful read that has a lot of fascinating twists to keep you clicking your Next Page button.

Like the way he uses character and story to explore sentience and quality of life probably in the near future. Neatly integrates politics, technology, AI, genetics, quality of life in multiple settings, ethics and related issues through the arc of the story.  In some ways like listening to a genius level thinker and writer expound on his thoughts and insights garnered from his own studies and fairly wide reading of other great minds in history.
summary: Very good exercise on several subjects, including the emortality concept advanced by the author.

reviewText: Covering a seminal period, Wawro proves he's  a rising star among military historians. Pity that he continues to ignore Schleswig-Holstein.

Very good reference on improving school attendance. Case studies and sample attendance policy included. Motivating students to go to school regularly and punctually is not enough; children's education is a collaboration of school, parents/carers, local community and government. The book emphasised on student monitoring through letters,phone calls or home visits.
summary: school, attendance, education, united kingdom, scotland

reviewText: As a high school student wanting to know more about Chinese Communism, this was a great read... Lots of information which was easy to comprehend even though I did not have much knowledge about China.

I bought this book by accidentally pressing the wrong button on my Kindle. I was actually in Agra at the time and was very disappointed with it. Its not worth the $43 and feels like its just the authors academic study. I doubt its going to sell much.

Got this book on Kindle Fire and love the content.  However the photos, which illustrate the text and are of great importance, are so small as to be unviewable.  Tried different ways to blow them up to some reasonable size, all to no avail.  Downloaded the book to a PC but the illustrations still stay stubbornly micro size.  The rating of only 2 stars reflect this fact.Not having the photos, not only mars the pleasure of reading the book, but makes understanding the points the author makes difficult.  Ramparts, city gates and other architectural elements cannot be visualized.  Maps of settlement patterns cannot be discerned.Does anybody knows a way to see properly these illustrations?  Did the author maybe place them on same shared photo site where they could be viewed.  Without this I cannot recommend getting this book in the Kindle store.

This is a great introduction to the subject of biblical archaeology. The author offers an intense focus on archaeological study--he presents methods and evidence, rather than theory. Granted, there is theory, but it is often a skeptical analysis of other theory. There is an odd ratio of pictures on the work : many more at the end than in the beginning. Many were taken by Laughlin himself, who, if I may say so, isn't too bad a photographer.This book is a good read, though I wouldn't pay $125.00 for it.
summary: Review of Laughlin's 'Archaeology and the Bible'

reviewText: Absolutely awesome! Intelligently deals with the case for teaching with real books. This approach will put the joy back into learning to read, and hopefully save many from "death by phonics".
summary: Must read for teachers of reading

reviewText: This book addresses medieval archaeology and architecture and its text depends on the quality of its images and floor plans.  The Kindle Edition does a deplorable job of transferring the images and plans from the print version to this electric edition.  It is impossible to make out the graphs, the artwork is miniscule and the floor plans are rendered useless.  While it might be nice to save twenty dollars on the Kindle Edition, the hard copy is essential to grasping the author's argument and gaining a firm understanding of gendered architecture.
Solid introduction to the period and the issues.  Love the selected bibliography.

I bought this by accident, then decided to keep it. It's not terrible, it's simply mundane. At $3 it would rate three stars, but I expect a lot more for $14. If the price comes down and you're interested in Elizabeth don't expect a lot but go ahead and read it. At $14 it's a ripoff.
It's a really good read for those seeking to understand fantastic literature at an academic level.  It is very well written.
summary: Wonderful work studying the psychoanalytic perspectives on fantasy

reviewText: Too complex and subjective as all psychoanalytical works go, but insightful and certainly one of a kind. Had a hard time to read it through, and the term FANTASY is too broadly understood, but once again - a unique perspective of analysis for the genre anyway.
I was evaluating this book for class room work. It is well written and comprehensive, a good choice for advanced students.

Wow! I can't believe I threw away almost $8 on this. I was hoping to be able to learn about the battles and foreign idealist volunteer (or volunteered as in some cases) soldiers but instead I have to read about the political jockeying and uninteresting politicians that caused the war. This would be perfectly fine if it was a chapter or two long but it is instead the content of the entire book. If you think of yourself as a political scholar instead of an armchair general then you may enjoy this very dry study. Everyone else stay far far away from this purchase.
summary: Only concerned with the politics and reason for the war

reviewText: Just returned from seeing the movie "Gravity" and was struck by the fact that I now really only go to the movie theater to see FX spectacle and i stay home to watch narrative drama via TV (or what we once called TV) on my laptop.  It's my impression that much of Darley's excellent book anticipates this development.

I found the book very readable. I would have liked to have been told that it was using the Transactional Analysis method (mainly?), before reading it. Maybe it was on the cover of the printed version. I bought the e-book. I'd recommend it to anyone generally interested in the topic of counselling.
I got a recommendation from Amazon to read this, normally I ignore these.  But I am so happy I did not this time.  A great read as a counselling book and as a story.  Works on both fronts.

I bought this book because my daughter's councellor recommended she read it.As a person who has suffered from severe depression myself I found it very enlightening.The essential information is simply delivered. It is easy to get the big picture with its individual components. It is very cleverly woven into the Wind in the Willows story so that the information is delivered in context. I would recommend this book to a recovering depressive and anyone supporting a person struggling with depression.Excellent

While somewhat dated in terms of technologies available to the classroom and, of course, "veddy British" the philosophy of and approaches to teaching Communication are valuable to any instructor. As a mobile product it was a let-down in terms of no noted pagination and regarding the figures which weren't readable on my iPad's Kindle app.
Adey has several contributions solid, practical, psychological and pedagogical rich and clear. Every teacher most know his work, because he well find guides to improve his strategies to teach.
A useful guide for those completing research projects.  I will keep this book in my professional library as I will be conducting research on a few other subjects as my teaching career goes on.

A readable and accessible analysis of a number of children's book series, this book focuses on British, rather than American authors. An extensive section is devoted to Arthur Ransome, but L. M. Boston, Susan Cooper, Enid Blyton, and Antonia Forest (among others) are also included. Watson's analysis of the literary qualities of these authors is enlightening and readers interested in British popular fiction for children should find much to savor here.
summary: Readable history of children's book series

reviewText: A joy to read, while a bit old, great summary and introduction to people interested in learning more about tourism. Great for students. It would be great to expand the case studies. Beware of some of the problems of viewing the flowcharts, as usual most tables do not read that well, but Hey, affordable, informative, easy to read, I'm not complaining.
summary: Great book, begs an updated version!

reviewText: A Handbook for Action Research in Health and Social Care (Kindle Edition)by Richard Winter (Author)I am commenting on the Kindle edition only--not the content of the text, which I'm sure is useful.This book is NOT a good Kindle candidate. Viewed on the original Kindle the graphics are so tiny they are impossible to read, the tables are meaningless because the lack of formatting results in a long, bewildering list, and the table of contents as well as the index is not interactive. A handbook by definition needs to be able to be consulted; it is not meant to be read through like a novel. Very difficult to actually USE this handbook!Bad choice for the Kindle, and a complete waste of my money.
summary: Bad choice for Kindle delivery ... buy the hard copy or not at all.

reviewText: a good,short book,just the slightest bit boring.i would rate it 4 and a half,i liked the storyboard.

I'm editing my review because I was actually mistaken in something I said in it before. As others have said the story is very short, but also very well written and for the price I don't think you could do much better.I actually just went out today and bought a Star Wars novel by the same author about Darth Vader and so far it's even better.I'm not going to go over the plot or how short this tale is, as plenty of other reviews have already done that. I'm just throwing my own four star rating into the mix to help bump up his rating.
The only reason I didn't give this a better rating is because it was over too quickly.  Can't wait to read more about Darth Maul.  Go dark side!!!
A little short but a good read to fill in some gaps, gives Darth Maul's character a bit more depth
It was nice to read about Darth Maul and learn a little more about him since he didn't really do much in episode 1.

at 94 pages, i fear my review may be longer than the book.  still, this book marks an interesting beginning to the star wars e-book era.  i, personally, had hoped that they would have flexed the muscles of the e-book format.  simply put, i would have liked to have seen the ability to click on a word (such as weequay) and have an image appear with a brief explanation to reinforce the uninitiated reader's sense of wonderment.  alas, it IS a new format, sigh. the story itself is a simple "out and back" tale of darth maul being sent on his first solo mission for his master.  i had heard it was to be the tale of maul's assault on the black sun (as referred to in shadow hunter) and was dissappointed to find otherwise.  still, the tale was pleasureable.  for those of you who have read the jedi apprentice series by scholastic, it reminded me of the evil version of those.  i was even impressed that maul used the force to choke someone (my largest complaint of shadow hunter was that he never used anything other that his lightsaber to dispatch someone). the tale is well worth the price of admission.
summary: e-book worth $2- why not try it?

reviewText: I decided to read this short story not because I am a fan of Darth Maul but because James Luceno is probably my favorite SW author, and I am a long-time fan of SW so I decided to give it a shot. I don't care much for Maul and I think this story is a great example why; he never does anything important and there's not much intrigue surrounding him, both in this story and in general. The story is well written and has good pacing but due to it being a 'short story' and using a bland lead character that's about all it can muster IMO. I obtained this story in print version as it is now offered with Darth Maul: Shadow Hunter, by Michael Reaves, so I figured if I enjoyed Saboteur I may read SH. EDIT: I have since read Shadow Hunter and to my surprise I actually prefer Saboteur. I feel this story captured Maul's proficiency at espionage better than SH, and Saboteur also did a better job at making Maul the protagonist of the story. Despite my thoughts on Maul I can overlook a character's short-comings and be content with what I'm reading if there's a decent story to back him/her up; there just wasn't enough here to make that happen. Perhaps if it was a bit longer and the mission was a little more interesting... To me Maul remains a nobody goon, fortunate to be trained by a real Lord of the Sith, and I have yet to read/watch something that can convince me otherwise.
very short for a very short price.  bought as a e book so u know what ur gettingWorks for me

This is not a jaw-dropping, revelation-filled, "I am your father" story by any means, but if you're looking for more Darth Maul action, this is a good read, and it's quick.It was cool to see DM doing some stealth work instead of straight up slaughter.  Reminded me of an 80's action flick.This story also fills in some gaps in the EU.  Not important ones, but when you read the book Darth Plagueis and you wonder what the heck Darth Sideous is referencing, well this is one of those things.  Just read it already!  :)

Not exceedingly long, but worth the read.  The events that lead up to Darth Maul : Shadow Hunter.  Worth the money to download and read!  Maul is a great character, bound to be the Boba Fett of the first trilogy and worth reading about!  If you're a Star Wars fan this is a must, and if you're not it's still a great sci fi read!!!

This is a readable short story which holds the distinction of being, in Star Wars universe chronological terms and excluding the comic books, the very first piece of Star Wars literature.  This makes it a must read if you are a die hard Star Wars fan, but if you are not, $$$ are not worth the effort of download.  ( I am a fan, by the way. )The story sets the stage for the movie series by presenting the beginnings of the relationship between Darth Sidious and the Trade Federation which become central in Episodes I and II, answering some important questions and generally beefing up the back story.  The story is not really a Darth Maul story in the sense that there is the barest minimum of character development.  At 85 pages, the story can easily be read in one sitting and is more a narrative of events occasionally given from Darth Mauls perspective.James Luceno does an acceptable job in setting up the overall Star Wars atmosphere.  However, the characters are very stereotypical, requiring the reader to fill in the blanks from their own knowlege of the Star Wars universe....particularly weak on action prose.  ...
I was quite disappointed in this ebook. While it showed a different side of Darth Maul, I feel he was a better warrior than a cunning enemy.

I'm surprised that a book that is titled Darth Maul would have so little about him.  The very short story spends so much time setting up why Darth Maul is involved, it doesn't leave much time for Darth Maul himself.  Also has another conflict with another Darth Maul book.  In the other book, Dark Maul's master found the plans for his lightsaber in a type of Jedi history book.  In this one, Darth Maul made the decision to build it himself.Still, at under [price], it's still worth it.
my son is a devoted fan so of course he loves it.  Fits nicely to his collection - next please

I read this book over the course of about two-three hours, and it is just what my title says it is: a quick and dirty introduction to Darth Maul.  It introduces him as the apprentice to Darth Sydious, sets him up for his work with the Black Suns and the Trade Federation (which is covered in Darth Maul: Shadow Hunter), and starts the ball rolling for Episode I.
summary: Quick Dirty Introduction to Darth Maul

reviewerName: Darth Mortis "Dark Lord of the Sith"
reviewText: So I have to admit, Darth Maul is one of my favorite characters in the Star Wars universe and he just did not receive nearly enough attention in the Phantom Menace. That is why I am glad that the expanded universe has included a couple of volumes specific to him. Along with Darth Maul: Saboteur, there isShadow Hunter (Star Wars: Darth Maul)andStar Wars: Darth Maul, Edition# 1(which takes place right after this one).In this volume, we are taken to the world of Dorvalla, that has a highly sought after mineral. There are two competing mining companies that are looking for dominance: Intergalactic Ore and Lommite Limited (abbreviated LL throughout the book). Intergalactic has been sabotaging LL's ships and the recent one (closer to the beginning of the book) caused a lot of damage and enraged the CEO of the company. They make the decision to fight fire with fire, since going to the senate would be worthless. In comes Darth Maul, who is sent to make the situation favorable. The Sith are looking to set up a relationship with the Trade Federation, and this is a great way to do it. Without spoiling too much, the book is mostly espionage, both corporate and force wielding.Keep in mind that this book is short. If it was printed, it would be under 100 pages. The storyline is not overly complicated, unlike some of the others in the expanded universe. There is not a whole lot of action, it's more subterfuge than anything else. It's a good, quick read. I didn't think it was as focused on Darth Maul as the title led me to believe but that is really my only "complaint". Good book and definitely worth the buck and a half.
i loved darth bane saga. and maybe thats the problem. about the end i was wondering... any action? any sith long plan? no. is this an industrial sabotage story? yes. that is all.
This short story is a perfect addition to the novel Star Wars plageious, a excellent story of how darth maul accomplishes his tasks

....  I introduces Darth Maul's first mission, roughly a year prior to the events of Episode I.I will speak truth: the plot is extremely straightforward, and there is little, if anything, that complicates Maul's mission.  Even the death scenes are spartan and sterile.  For now, it seems that LucasFilm is just playing around with the e-book format, having a little fun before they get serious.All Darth Maul really has to do is sabotage (hint-hint) a couple of mining corporations.  As a hardcore SW fan, I fail to see how a lommite ore mining guild poses a threat to Darth Sidious' plans to take over the galaxy.  Nevertheless, that is the plot, and who am I to argue with history?  In the end, Maul pits the mining guilds against a group of mercenaries in a classic strategy: he only stands off to the side, waits for each group to exhaust themselves to death, and then he cleans up the mess.  Seriously, this novella could have been expanded a LOT more, and for once, adding some details and stretching out the plot of this book would actually make the story better.
summary: A fun romp through the Galaxy with Darth Maul

reviewText: Darth Maul working under cloak of darkness committing sabotage now that is a story worth reading many times over.  Great story.

This is a short story focused on Darth Maul's role in helping the Trade Federation gain a mining colony. It's not bad, but it's also nothing exceptional. It's fairly short so we don't really get to see any characters develop. The few events that do happen seem to go by quickly, including what should have been major battles. The story is included in the novelShadow Hunter (Star Wars: Darth Maul), which is worth reading, so don't bother to buy this one separately.

I found this story to be a good read. Just wish it had been a little longer but it does give more insight into the mind of Darth Maul and his relationship with Darth Sidious before his eventual defeat.

A few hundred more pages would suffice as this story was just getting good. This was a perfect set up piece for the next installment in the series and look forward to all and or any involving the awesome Darth Maul.

I've always enjoyed the books that fill in & around the movies, going back before E 1-3 were released. Saboteur definitely adds a few small facets to characters that help enrich the over Star Wars saga.

Read it very quickly, but for 3 bucks I felt I mostly got my money's worth.  I love the stories that take place right before Episode 1, so would only recommend to likeminded fans.  It goes well with Darth Maul: Shadow Hunter, Cloak of Deception and Darth Plagues.
An allright book. Only 50 pages long though. Some parts get boring but overall, a good read.
A good history about Darth Maul. Necesary to read this story before you view the episode I. If you are a fan don't miss this book.

For less than two dollars, one really can't complain about this title. Still, I did not find this story compelling at all -we get no "feel" for any of the characters. The story is told more in a documentary style with a presentation of the facts than anything else. As I said, you get what you pay for, I guess.
