reviewText: It was mostly an index of what your dreams may mean and many I have never experienced

This is a richly written, beautifully conceived novel of the magnetic attraction of evil and its destructive nature. Pretty much all of the seven deadly sins - and possibly a few not thought of before - dog the lives of an Australian father, his son and daughter, as well as his wife. The father's fantasies lure him into darkness and death, the son expresses that darkness in paintings and plays while imbibing in a near-incestuous relationship with his sister, the mother - a fantasist of a different sort - is released for remarriage when her husband suicides. Set in Melbourne, Australia, the city is hazily sketched in the background of the story, except the seediest parts of town that attract these characters and others to a doom of sorts. The son gets away to Europe, marries, enjoys success of a sort, but is drawn back to Melbourne only to swirl around the darkening drain of sex, jealousy, anger and lack of success, ending a grim but beautifully told tale.

What ever possessed me to download this book?  Within a few pages you get the feeling that you are in a murky, gross, perverted presence, filled with forboding.  After two short sessions trying to understand what had moved me to put this on my Kindle, I felt like I needed to take a long, hot shower.  I decided life is too short...the book is gone, gone, gone from my Kindle.  Good riddance!
summary: Could I Rate This NO Stars, Please?

reviewerName: Jessss "I read to find stories that inspire m...
reviewText: The Walters are an eccentric family who struggles through life. They go from the allies and back parts of Melbourne to Europe which is struggling of war. This book has plenty of magic and brothels and fortune tellers and even some predators. The world of obsessions and crimes is a world that can draw even the best in and the Walters are no exception. With a disintegrating marriage, the children are exposed to a city's possibilities and Paul and Ondine are no exception. It is set between the time of 1891 and 1922 and the writer captures the historical side of it and flows through the plot very easily. With everyday family matters and believable plot twists this books has plenty for a reader to enjoy. Abuse, murder, love, war are just some of what you see and the action and draw is great.

This is a strange, but interesting historical novel. Once it hits its stride, it's a page-turner. The story follows the fate of an aspiring artist whose ambition ends up destroying him. Along the way we encounter a world of extreme eccentricity that highlights the seedy side of city life. There are some wonderfully bizarre characters, including a conman who may be the devil, and an epileptic poet who also seems to be anorexic. A lot of the novel is set in nineteenth-century Melbourne. It does a great job evoking a vanished city of arcades and alleyways. The novel won an Aurealis Award for the best Australian horror novel, but it doesn't really fit into that genre. More a work of Gothic or decadent fiction. And not a book for prudes.

The book started off strongly, with the introduction of possible suspects, and the murder of others.  If you like who-done-it books, you may find this book interesting.  However, towards the middle and end of the book, everything feels rushed, as if trying to fit all the information into a set number of pages.  Character development declines, and characters you may have been interested in are eliminated.  Trying to figure out the who did it and why, and how each character is interconnected  to be solved as a contest is an intriguing idea, and it's a great gimmick for book sales.  On the downside, the book is useless unless you eventually know what the real answer was and what the winner wrote.  With enough searching, you can find out who won, but 2 years later, I still haven't found the correct answer (this requires you to have written for the request before the deadline).  If anyone found the correct answer, please let the rest of us know.
summary: Fun mystery to try to solve

reviewText: Tiffany Jones is a former disco diva who fell from grace in the '80s. She is well on her way to making a comeback when she is found dead in her dressing room after missing her curtain call at the Apollo Theater. Although the circumstances surrounding her death do not seem out of the ordinary, Tiffany's manager Kim Carlyle is not so sure. Tiffany's demise sets off a series of strange occurrences, and as the story evolves, WHO KILLED TIFFANY JONES? becomes one of several questions needing an answer in this interactive mystery novel. A Techno-geek like myself would also enjoy interacting with the book, a web site, and maybe other readers, tracking my progress with an online log of some sort. WHO KILLED TIFFANY JONES? could easily spark a movement of more interactivity in the mystery genre.Reviewed by Elisa Kai Smith
How do I find outas of April 20, 2013 who killed Tiffany Jones? I don't believe that the book should be sold in this way because it is incomplete. If it were possible I would like a refund.

I loved this book from beginning to end, I orginally read the book back in 2002 right after it was released and I met the author who awarded me with a scholarship for another contest with one of his books, and I just recently read this novel again and I was amazed at how the book had me on the edgr of my seat again trying to figure out who di it. I recommend that any and evryone should read this book and try to figure it out I believe this is an excellent book with an great storyline.

Entertainment agent Kim Carlyle is flying high when one of her clients, internationally known singer Tiffany Jones, is on the comeback trail. Unfortunately, that comeback comes to a screeching halt one hot summer night in New York City. Instead of making a scheduled performance at the world famous Apollo Theatre. Tiffany Jones is making an appearance at the city morgue, with a toe tag as her most distinctive accessory.Tiffany's death sets the music world abuzz because something just does not seem quite right about her death. Kim believes her client has been murdered and is prepared to let the police handle the investigation. When another of her clients is murdered, she has to get involved, Kim is a former New York City police officer, so investigating crimes is like breathing to her. As Kim digs into her investigation, she uncovers a trail of dead bodies with an international connection.Who Killed Tiffany Jones is a suspense filled mystery that will keep readers on their toes. It also has a unique twist; instead of providing readers with the solutions to the crimes, the book provides the reader with the opportunity to solve the murders and the chance to win $10,000 if the reader comes up with the correct solution. If you had any doubts about reading this novel, cast them aside, reading Who Killed Tiffany Jones might pay off.Reviewed by Simone A. Hawks

reviewText: I do enjoy reading about orangutans, field studies and exotic environments (Borneo). I also enjoy reading about sci-fi medical stuff. This reads very much like a YA adventure and a majority of the interesting sci-fi gene/cloning experimentation was treated as background info rather than the focus of the book. I wish this aspect had been given more emphasis. Tay (cloned human - one of 5 clones who are now teenagers) and her younger 'brother' Donny (natural child of her adoptive father and mother) spend the summer at a rescue site for orphaned orangs in Borneo where their 'parents' work. Political drama ends with the destruction of the study site while the Tay and Donny are exploring a cave site. Bad things happen and the two, along with Uncle, an orang from Sumatra and Clint, a scientist with a Clint Eastwood obsession, attempt to travel miles and miles to another study site where Tay's clone-mamma works. More bad things happen. Ended with a lot of loose threads related to the cloning issues....and very little happens in terms of the 4 other clone-teens.From an adventure story perspective, this book does a good job. From the perspective of a sci-fi medical thriller, it falls short. I enjoyed the read but felt much of the interesting stuff wasn't given enough emphasis. The book had a semi-Crichton vibe to it ala Jurassic Park....but read more like some of the freebies/99 cent reads I've picked up. I don't think it was worth the price I paid (sigh).
summary: could have been much better - enjoyed the Borneo setting

reviewText: Zahn is the best writer in the SW universe. Another good story from him. His writing style is very good.

Timothy Zahn's Fool's Bargain is a short story originally published in e-book form and set before the events of his novel Survivor's Quest. This tale covers an assignment Aurek Company of the Imperial 501st receives on the embattled planet Kariek. The focus is on the four troopers who comprise Aurek-Seven and in particular their leader Twister. This is the same squad that plays a part in Survivor's Quest, minus one personnel change which is detailed in this story. There aren't many Expanded Universe stories that take the Imperial point of view, so this is a welcome perspective here. By this stage in the galaxy's history, years after the Battle of Endor, certain elements of the Empire have developed a more enlightened perspective of the universe around them. These troopers are honorable soldiers fighting for a government they believe in, one that no longer ruthlessly oppresses subject populations but rather plays more of a protector role.The Empire of the films is notably a human-centric organization. Zahn opens the door to alien Imperials in this story with the introduction of Su-mil, an Eickarie and a Kariek native swept up in a civil war. There is a clever bit of deception on Su-mils part involving the Eickarie concept of a lie (they term a lie "left-handed," vs. a truth which is "right-handed" - this must be awkward for the native left-handed Eickaries!). By fighting together, Twister sees a potentially valuable ally in Su-mil and we get a perspective of how a stormtrooper unit might be something a soldier would actually aspire to join, rather than simply being cannon fodder for Rebel heroes.All in all, Fool's Bargain is an enjoyable vignette of Imperial life that expands a bit on characters from Survivor's Quest and also provides an interesting preview of the Imperial perspective Zahn went on to explore more thoroughly in his novel Allegiance. It can be purchased in electronic form and is also available in the paperback version ofSurvivor's Quest (Star Wars).
Not too bad, an intro-short-story for some bigger upcoming novel. It's timothy Zahn, what did you expect from the master of Science Fiction.

While somewhat short and fairly straightforward, this was a nice bit of military sci-fi action in the Star Wars universe. I'm a big fan of anything involving the Unknown Regions, especially when it's written by Zahn. This was a cool, quick, action-packed story that leaves you wanting more.  If you're expecting a lengthy installment, this isn't it. But that doesn't mean it's not worth the read.
Fool's bargain is a novella that reads like full novel. It also is a great setup for Survival Quest. M

For whatever reason, Star Wars short stories are a bit of a hit or miss. The "Tales of..." are great in that they explain background characters. However,Fool's Bargaindidn't really fit the bill. It's a short story about a relatively minor and unmemorable character from Timothy Zahn'sSurvivor's Quest (Star Wars). The story itself is basically about stormtroopers storming a fortress with some mysterious Warlord. Unlike most of Zahn's other work, this is mostly a book of action, not intricate plot development. In fact, the story ends with an exciting twist, but doesn't develop it. I feel like this short story would have been better had it been about a character we all know and love, or included a really interesting plot twist. Also, just to note, this same story is included in the paperback copy ofSurvivor's Quest (Star Wars), so there's no need to buy the separate Kindle version.

I enjoyed the book because I really like Zahn. Although I didn't read enough of the product to realize it was only a novella. I finished the book in 2 nights and was hungry for more. If you like Zahn then it is a good purchase after all it is only a few dollars for it.

"Fool's Bargain" provides some interesting insight to modern EU Stormtroopers, and their processes. The story manages to dispel the "mindless order-following, killing-machine" reputation historically attributed to Stormtroopers, while also providing further insight into the 501st, and the development of the unit, post-Palpatine era. The story is short enough that it draws you into the story without dragging things out and bogging down, when most people will be eager to get the main story that "Fool's bargain" precedes ("Survivor's Quest".) The only complaint would be that the main focus of the story (or at least, whose view-point the story is written from) is an interesting Stormtrooper character named 'Twister'. Zahn makes him interesting enough that you look forward to learning more about him during "Survivor's Quest", yet every Stormtrooper character from "Fool's Bargain" appears heavily in "Survivor's Quest" *except* Twister, with no explanation as to why he is excluded. On the plus side, Zahn takes characters who would be previously seen as completely lacking of any real personality or character development, and draws you into their story rather quickly. Of course, anyone who is familiar with Zahn's work won't be surprised by that fact.
If you are a Star Wars fan I highly recommend this book to you. It is definitely one of Mr. Zahns' best works.

As an ebook it reads very well on my Kindle, but it really doesn't seem to belong where it is. Maybe at the end of The Dark Nest Trilogy or Legacy of the Force, but it just seems not to have a place it belongs in the Star Wars universe. At least not to me.
Really cool and action packed. Good for any star wars fan. Can read and enjoy for a long time. Can make you feel like you are in the book.

As a short story this is densely packed with action and character back story without feeling rushed. I think it expands the scope of the setting quite nicely. Expanding this dimension opens up a new view on previous stories as well.

reviewText: ** Note: this story appears as a bonus in the paperback edition of Survivor's Quest. **Fool's Bargain is a short story featuring the stormtroopers of Aurek-Four, a unit of the Imperial 501st Legion of the Empire of the Hand.  It takes place shortly before the events of Survivor's Quest, but is probably best read after.The Empire of the Hand is involved in a war to rid the native Eickarie people of their latest warlord, but the 501st curious orders are very specific - take the warlord alive.  This story is tightly focused, with a couple of characters firmly at the center.  There's good detail here but for some reason it doesn't feel as well developed as other short stories I've read by Zahn.  Also,  those who look for big names in their Star Wars stories will want to give this a pass.  A couple of minor characters from Survivor's Quest show up in largely supporting roles, but there are no movie characters nor beloved favorites here.But despite these caveats Fool's Bargain is a good short story that gives further glimpse of Zahn's take on stormtroopers, which he touched on in Survivor's Quest, and would continue to explore in later novels (Allegiance and Choices of One).

I admit it, I snapped this up the moment I saw it on new releases, because I tend to do that with anything written by Timothy Zahn. He is, in my opinion, one of the best contemporary sci-fi authors where it comes to world building, intricate plot, and edge-of-seat action. His Thrawn and Conqueror's trilogies were incredible, Quadrail and Cobra were very unique and engaging, and even his one-off novels like Icarus Hunt and Outbound Flight are excellent. So I figured this would be too.First off, when I hit the end my jaw dropped and I literally said aloud "Huh? That's it?!" I then spent several minutes looking to see if it picked up somewhere else. It is a really short story, barely longer than some of the ones that appear in the 'Tales' Star Wars series (and those books have several of them!). It's also, I must say, a lot less interesting than most of them and probably the single weakest plot I've seen Zahn write. It's not terrible, but it really isn't that great either- there's no twists and at the end you're left wondering where the other half of the story is. The novella revolves around a force of Stormtroopers who are only somewhat memorable (as is the case with most such white-armored shock troops) and though there is quite a bit of action, it kind of reads like a (short) movie or videogame script.Overall, not worth paying for. In fact, it should really be free if you ask me.

I love Timothy Zahn's work!  He does what no other writer, not even George Lucas himself can do.  He takes the rank and file Storm Troopers and gives them personalities, talents, skills and makes them multi-dimensional characters that people can get invested in.Where most writers show the Storm Troopers as faceless cannon fodder who can't hit anything with their blasters, Zahn shows them as competent sharpshooting elite commandos who can think on their feet and adapt to any situation as well as follow orders.***SPOILERS***  ***SPOILERS***  ***SPOILERS***So the story is a pretty basic one.  There is an alien warlord who is ruling a planet with an iron fist, and the Empire decides it is time to go and free the plant of his rule, so they dispatch the 501st Legion a.k.a. Vader's Fist to take him down.There is something I do wonder about though, this takes place after Vader is dead, and after Thrawn's rule has ended.  So why does the 501st Legion keep calling themselves "Vader's Fist?"  Vader's not around anymore?  Do they keep the name just for the sake of nostalgia?  It's not really a major gripe, just something that makes me scratch my head.Our main characters are three Storm Troopers who all have different skills and specialties.  They infiltrate the warlord's fortress and meet up with some of the local freedom fighters and strike a deal with them.  If the troopers help them free their imprisoned comrades, they will help the troopers get inside and take out the warlord's troops and bring him to justice.The troopers agree and they infiltrate the stronghold together.  Later it seems the rebels have betrayed the Storm Troopers, but it turns out it is just a very elaborate ruse and the rebels were always on the side of the troopers and the prisoners are freed and the warlord is captured by the Empire and brought to justice.Later the head of the rebels is offered a position in the 501st Legion, which is awesome!  It really helps to enforce the fact that the Empire has learned that just having humans in their military doesn't help, it's a hindrance and it was the main reason the Rebel Alliance was able to defeat them.***END SPOILERS***  ***END SPOILERS***  ***END SPOILERS***Zahn gives us action, gun fights, intrigue and a little bit of politics as well in this story.  Any fan of Star Wars or Zahn's writing will enjoy this book very much!

Assistant district attorney Mary Crow is an excellent prosecutor and genuinely nice person but she has one small problem.  She keeps seeing a dead man and it unnerves her so much that she is seeing a psychiatrist who believes she's suffering from Post Traumatic Stress Disorder.  The police and the FBI believe that Stump Logan, known conspirator against the U.S. government and the suspect in the murders of Mary's parents died in the explosion at Russell Cove.Nobody knows that Logan is still alive and Mary did see him three times when he was looking for an opportunity to kill her.  He has now come up with a scheme to force Mary to come to him by kidnapping her goddaughter Lily.  At first the police don't take the abduction seriously, thinking it is a domestic dispute.  As Mary begins receiving e-mails of Lily, she realizes Stump lives and decides to use herself as bait, a risky move that might get her killed.Sallie Bissell has written as extremely exciting crime thriller about an obsession taken to extremes and the tragic results that happen because of that compulsion.  The protagonist comes across as a very sympathetic person, leading to readers rooting for her to triumph over the adversary she knows about and the one who has stayed in the shadows waiting for the right time to strike.  CALL THE DEVIL BY HIS OLDEST NAME is a pulse pounding, adrenaline-pumping novel that the audience will remember long after finishing the last page.Harriet Klausner
This one has keeps you reading with some interesting twists and turns and a protagonist who is raw evil.  I would recommend it.
summary: Well done with sub plots a plenty

reviewText: The graphics you see tells you that this is the Mandelbaum translation, which is my favorite and preferred version of the Comedy. However, what you get is NOT that - it's the hoary old public-domain Cary translation in prose format. I'm frankly surprised that Amazon would let something like this through. VERY disappointing, to say the least.
Want to see the first pitchfork-wielding demons?  Did you know Hell is frozen over?  Want to see Dante and Virgil go toe to toe with the denizens of Hell?  What are you waiting for?  Get reading!
summary: How can you beat a tourists guide to Hell?

reviewText: The advertised edition is the translation done by Mandelbaum.  What you ACTUALLY get is the Cary translation, which is in the public domain, and can be downloaded for free elsewhere in the Kindle store.
The kindle edition is linked to the Fagles translation, but that is not what you will get.  The Pope translation is what you will get for kindle -- not at all the same thing!Patricia
Beautiful language - moved me through time.
LOVE THIS PLAY it is in my top ten of favorite plays from Shakespeare. Is great to read and easier than most to understand

This is some weird victorian translation.  With some gems like "Remember how long thou hast been putting off these things, and how often thou hast received an opportunity from the gods, and yet dost not use it."  Awesome, if for some reason you enjoy superfluous victorian english.  It is like someone wanted to translate this text from the Greek of ~200AD and stop at 1600AD english and for some reason not go all the way to modern.  This is neither literal nor a translation that takes liberties in order to help understanding, but rather it is for those that would like some gratuitous difficulty.  If that is you, I don't judge, you might like this book.  However, if you just want a good translation look elsewhere. I thought Russel McNeil's was better though not great.
Timeless wisdom from ancient Rome useful for the post-modern world, this is a great evening read or end of the work day book to clear the mind & refresh the senses.
summary: Marcus Aurelius is masterful in wisdom.

reviewText: An absolutely inspired way of looking at the world. Makes you look at all your relationships in a new light.

Legendary book you should get your hands on this.  Timeless and humble lessons everyone can learn from.  Some parts get a little weird but take the good out of this, there's a lot of gold nuggets of wisdom here.

Very hard to follow - brain twister. So is Clinton reading this all these years to try to understand it or am I just not a audio learner. I am sure it has got some good stuff but I got a life to live.
summary: President Clinton ... Your a better man than me ----- obviously

reviewText: For modern casual readers, some familiarity to the Writing of Marcus Aurelius is a mark of a well educated person. However,  a detailed acquaintance is unnecessary and a bit boring except for scholars.

This book is one of the best books that I have ever read. The entire action of the book is very well structured  and almost every person in the book is carefully  described without  omitting a single detail.

For somebody whose mother tongue is not English this book makes very difficult reading. It took me two full monthes to reach the end. I find the style rather cumbersome and pompous even allowing it's been written almost two centuries ago, stuffed as it is with Nessus'shirt, Briareus'wrestle and the like. And it's a pity because I found it really interesting, full of a lot of details that bring to new life the time and the events, usually aseptically reported in proper history books. On the whole: hard reading but well worth the effort.
Good read after all these years, but so different from the movie! Glad I read it, though. That's about all I've got.
I purchased this e-book and found that it differed slightly from other editions. It's not a huge deal, but it might help someone to consider their purchase.
I have enjoyed this work since my days in high school.  Masters wonderfully portrays the lives of those in the book each with their own tragedy, trials, and triumphs in life.

Zuleika is a vain and shallow girl who breaks hearts wherever she goes. She makes a living as a stage magician, getting by more on her looks than her skill. Since she lives for being admired, this gives her a perfect way to make a living. She didn't enjoy being a governess, and never stayed with any situation long since the older sons in the family inevitably fell for her, forcing the family to let her go. When she visits Oxford, you can't help rooting for the Duke of Dorset when he proposes to her. As much as I adore Max Beerbohm's literary style, irony, and wit, this is a rather depressing book in which men destroy their lives in droves over their unrequited love for Zuleika. I have a feeling Sir Beerbohm did not have a very healthy attitude toward women.
It was magically and imaginative for dreamers and people who see the world in their own way with magic and strange animals

In this, the fifth of his Palliser Chronicles, Anthony Trollope moves Plantagenet Palliser and his vivacious wife, Glencora, squarely to the forefront.  Oddly, for me, this leads to one of his weakest efforts.  Of course, second-rate Trollope is better than most other writer's best efforts, so it's somewhat churlish to complain.  But I wish I believed a little more in the plotting here.  Palliser's ascendency to the Prime Ministership seems a stretch, and the accompanying storyline about the vile Ferdinand Lopez and his marital difficulties are not particularly involving.  True, when the two threads combine, it produces some interesting dilemmas for all concerned (culminating in a dramatic and evocative death), but not enough to engage me as fully as I would have hoped.  To be honest, I had a hard time getting through "The Prime Minister," which has never happened before when I've read this author.  As a piece of the Palliser puzzle, this is a vital entry in the canon...just not its best.
The flow of the story is slow and gets to be uninteresting. Of course, I am used to reading Jane Austen, Philippa Gregory, Jean Plaidy and other similar books.It is well-written, though.
summary: Disappointed with the flow of the narrative.

reviewText: I just read this for the first time at 36 years of age, and I really liked it.  Rebecca reminded me of Anne Shirley from Anne of Green Gables.  She's a strong lead character with a ton of charm, stubborness, imagination and courage.  But unlike the Avonlea books, Rebecca of Sunnybrook farm is a single book.  And it shouldn't be.  The one downfall of this delightful book is that it ended!  You are left wondering what happens to Rebecca.  If she attains the aspirations of her patrons Mr. Aladdin and her high school teacher.  I thought for sure there were more "Rebecca" books and was very disappointed that this was the only one.

I am amazed at the imagery that Coleridge uses in this short poem.  It is so profound and powerful.  The christian themes are done do well.  The way the Mariner tells his story is fascinating in every way.

reviewText: This is a vivid portrait of one Jewish man's  experience of immigrating to America in the late 1800s. If you want to witness a man's journey into assimilation while losing his moral compass, if you want to read of love's treacherous road, if you want a visualization of  the Lower East side in times past, this is the book for you.  Written in 1925, it retains it's modernity to this day.

From our present day sensitivities, the novel is as politically incorrect as you can get. Still, I enjoy novels from this time period (pre nuclear). I remember the old dr. Fu man chu movies. Read with a grain of salt, they are a fun read.
summary: the insidious dr. fu man chu

reviewText: Loved this book as I did the last one. Her short stories keep one coming back for more. Think she's wonderful
Enjoyed this read very much.  Characters were made to come alive.  Found myself wishing the stories were longer to know more about how their stories went on.
Either way, read the book. It's a fun read. My professor said it was supposed to be fun anyway. I was more creeped out than anything else. Half the class agreed with me.

reviewText: Of course, a wonderful story ... but a sloppy edition which is obviously just a cut and paste of the project gutenberg text, with no formatting or illustrations.If this represents the standard of the 90,000 Kindle editions above and beyond what is produced out of the mainstream publishing business, this will be an interesting evolution ...
This book is in an easy to use format, but is a little wordy, and not as compelling a story as the other book I have read by Elizabeth Gaskell, "Wives and Daughters".

I so badly wanted to like this book.  Gaskell's life, Charles Dicken's very high regard and the books description boded well for a great read.  Instead what I found was tedious, overwritten, under-storied and poorly drawn.  This book had promise.  I can not see what Dickens saw and praised.

Yes, they are melodramatic and the characters seem to love talking more than acting but despite that I enjoyed reading this first effort by Elizabeth Gaskell, especially when I found out that it was based on an actual 1831 murder.The story follows Mary Barton, whose father has been implicated in the death, through her adolescence when she falls for a mill owners son rather than the steady young man who does love her. Fortunately, she can be stubborn but not foolish. The first half is kind of slow but picks up speed in the second half and it does a good job of describing the time period and the rather dreadful lives of factory workers.

Rich man, poor man. What it was like in Victorian England in the early 19th century. Gaskell, I believe, was so incredibly honest. She didn't pull any punches. Just be glad that you didn't live then even if you have it 'hard' now. I love the scenes she paints for the reader. Not everything she writes has the proverbial happy ending.
It took a bit get into, but ended up really enjoying it. Would probably read again. Another good read by E. Gaskell.
summary: took a bit get into, but ended up really enjoying it.

reviewText: I had never heard of Elizabeth Gaskell and was drawn to her writings as a result of watching a short BBC series which I loved based on another of her novels.  There is so much insight to be gained from reading an author writing about his/her time in history, much like Dickens.  Her writings, however, are more easily read than Dickens' and seem to me to be less stilted than his work sometimes comes across.  I loved it!

I have read almost all of Gaskells works and really like her writings. This one is one of the bests. Many say it is her best, but I believe North and South is. Mary Barton, like most of Gaskell's books, has several good moral points. Definitely worth reading and would recommend to young people, too.
Haven't read it so I probably shouldn't say anything in this review.  Wish I had so that I could leave a spoiler in this review.

I could read it once, would not recommend " Mary Barton" to any of my friends.  I found it not as good as "North and South".
summary: It is Ok, nothing more to say.

reviewText: The reviewer above must not know much about Victorian Condition of England novels. Mary Barton is one of the premier novels of this genre detailing the lives of ordinary working class poor in Manchester during the height of the industrial revolution. Mrs. Gaskell lived in Manchester and writes about what she saw with a keen eye and understanding of the workers' plight. If you're looking for bodice-ripping buy something else. If you want a picture of life in England circa 1840 that isn't Dickens, try Mary Barton.

Loved this book!  The more I read, the more passionate I felt about deep topics--poverty, hatred, forgiveness, redemption, and integrity. The leading characters are painted in such a way that when they hurt, I hurt and when they destroyed their lives, I cried for them. Elizabeth Gaskell, who worked among the impoverished people she wrote about, convinces us that true "nobility" exists among all classes of people and it is more a reflection of one's character than a profile of one's wealth.This book is full of timeless principles that are every bit as applicable in our day as they were in hers.Thankfully, I read this as part of a book club so I had an outlet to share and discuss the many burning questions that Gaskell created.  I am a better person for having read this book.  It is a great love story, too! :)
Mary Barton is a social novel. It has a political agenda that was current in the time it was written.
summary: Not Light reading but worth it

reviewText: Truth and honesty to a world of desperate people looking for the answer to life which only Christ can fulfill.

Mary Barton, published in 1848, was Elizabeth Gaskell's first novel.  Originally titled "John Barton," it's a book with many elements - starting out as a exploration of the lives of the poor in Manchester, England and ending as a more traditional love story with a focus on economic justice.Mary is John's daughter, a young dressmaker who enters into a flirtation with the son of a factory owner.  She hopes to marry him and rescue herself and her father from poverty.  Jem, a factory foreman who is the son of one of her father's closest friends, is in love with Mary.  As economic conditions worsen in Manchester, Mary's father is radicalized and drawn into Chartism (not incredibly well known now, this was a working class labor movement).As all these elements come together, Gaskell mixes romance, a murder trial, a strike, and heartrending descriptions of poverty and death.  There are a handful of characters who are economically well-off and they're not presented unsympathetically, but it's clear that Gaskell's heart was with the working class characters of this novel.  Their dialect is carefully presented (with glosses in the text, provided by her husband) and her desire is clearly that her readers would understand - if not condone - how their lives are lived.  Esther, an aunt of Mary's who has become a prostitute, is even given a chance to explain her actions and why she has made the choices that she has made.While I did enjoy this book, parts of the second half did drag for me.  Gaskell had not yet mastered the art of authorial injections and the constant breaking in began to feel a bit intrusive.  There were also some bits of high-Victoriana I could have done without (a "fit of madness" that leaves one ill for a few weeks, etc).Wives and Daughters, from the end of her career, was a much stronger novel.  However, there is still a great deal to enjoy here and I look forward to reading more novels by this unfairly underknown novelist.

This book will cut you to the quick. It not only asks you to think differently but demands that you take action. What good will it do you to say I had the world's goods and did naught for my brother because I was ignorant?
This is a moving tale of factory life in nineteenth century England that still holds truths for today. A must-read classic!
A fascinating tale of working-class England in the1830s. Drama and mystery abound as characters are sketched and developed and plots are skillfully intertwined. Well worth the read.

I loved Wives and Daughters and looked forward to more from Elizabeth Gaskell.  This is a bit long winded but the storyline is pretty good.  The language and expressions are a nice change from most of the more modern authors.

What we learn is human nature will out - the world is, and ever was, populated with the foolish, the earnest, the greedy, the powerful all applying their human behaviour to the benefit/detriment of themselves and others. Historically sound and an excellent reminder that history repeats........

This is a dated Victorian melodrama, but that said, it's still a must-read to get a feel for the period and the sheer awfulness of working-class life in the 1840s. The first third is the best, but Gaskell was apparently told to knock off the social commentary and substitute romance instead, so the latter two thirds are of less interest to a modern reader - there's an awful lot of swooning and fainting going on. Nevertheless, dramatic and gripping, even if cheesy as heck. I cared about the characters and wanted to know what happened to them.
summary: A must-read, but a showing its age

reviewText: I couldn't bear to read more than a few pages.  I think I stopped at page 35, & I probably actually read only about 3 pages worth of that.  It is filled with long & tedious descriptions of the setting, & I am not interested in reading a book that I will skim through the majority of.

Excellent insights into the minds and hearts of working-class Victorian people, and faithful depiction of their daily lives. I cared about these characters and what happened to them, so this was a page-turner for me.

In this first novel by Elizabeth Gaskell, we follow the life of Mary Barton, daughter of a mill-worker and union man, growing up in Manchester during a time of unrest between workers and employers.Depecting many of the well-known themes of all of Gaskell's works (rich vs. poor, relationships between children and parents), this is a deeply realistic novel. It's not a pleasant read, with all the sorrow going on in the story, but I think in her (Gaskell's) time this was a novel that should be written, clearly depicting the social problems of the mid-19th century. It is a very Victorian novel, with among others typical high (melo)drama and noble 'savages' playing an important part. Comparing it to other Gaskell books I've read, I wasn't surprised finding out this was her first novel. The prose is a bit rusty and I think in her later books she comes more into her own with more realistic character development and better story pacing.
summary: Gaskell's first novel not as good as her later work

reviewText: Elizabeth Gaskell writes classic English novels with a deep understanding of human nature.  Her stories are well written and full of good descriptions about the time period;  they also are very entertaining to read.
summary: This is a very good book

reviewText: Thiz is a short book, and I wish it had gone on longer.  Written in (I'm guessing) the late 1800's or very early 1900's, it is a guide to the wildlife, geology, weather, wildflowers, trees and people of the Sierra Mountains in California, around the turn of 19th and 20th centuries.  The author clearly spent a great deal of time observing life around her, as well as the times and seasons in the mountains.  Most unusual and most wonderful, for the time, is her sympathetic and respectful writing of the Indians and Hispanics in the area.  There is no hint of prejudice common to other writings of the time.The archaic Victorian sentence structure was a bit of a bother; the author did enjoy long convoluted sentences.  At times, I found myself re-reading a sentence over several times to figure out what the heck she meant.  However, after a while, I got used to it, and was able to pull out the meaning with little trouble.  This slight difficulty in reading was the only reason I gave it 4 stars rather than 5.I would recommend this book to anyone interested in the natural history of the American desert.
summary: A Glimpse of Sierra Mountain Life

reviewText: "A pair of  Blue Eyes" is one the least well known of Hardy's works. I discovered his novels and poetry years ago and treasured his great contribution to literature.  This novel however is not on the level of other works of his thus the three stars. Anyone with a modicum of knowledge in literature learns to analyze and value different genre's by reading the classics.
I believe this is a much more believable accounting from one of the survivors of this tragedy.  Secondhand accounts tend to sensationalism in reporting a story.  I enjoyed this book very much.

reviewText: Good story, well written. I would recommend this for anyone who wants direct information about the Titanic disaster from someone who was there.
One feels the truth in this narrative. It is a very moving tale of the happenings on the Titanic at the moment of her birth and readable. Very readable.

I thought this book was so interesting from the first person aspect.  Having seen a few movies about the Titanic, and visiting museums with special exhibits of Titanic artifacts, I could imagine everyhing written in the book.

What better accounting of the most famous disasters of the 20th century than to have a literate and observant survivor tell his story--with all the veritable details?  I definitely got a sense of what it was like to be on board the SS Titanic--before, during, and after its demise.
I read this book in one sitting. Spellbound by Beesleys account of the tragedy: I'm glad he lived a long life!
This is the first book I have read about the Titanic,  and I wanted an account from a survivors view.

I chose this rating because of Shakespeare's story telling.  I thought the bloodshed was a little too graphic, because the maiming and murders could have been alluded to rather than carried out on the stage.  It would be  hard hard to stage on the stage without upsetting much of the audience.
summary: A tale of blood and murder based on vengeance

reviewText: Overall, a passable Kindle edition.Does not have an active table of contents. In fact, it has no table of contents at all.The text is clean. Well, at least I didn't see any typographical errors.If Sax Rohmer continued in this book his practice of using italics to emphasize occasional words, then those emphases seem to have been lost in this edition--as they were in the ManyBooks (free) digital edition. Maybe that's preferable to how word emphasis has been handled in some digital editions of the first book in this series (The Insidious Dr. Fu Manchu). In those editions, emphasized words were set in all capitals, which is distracting. The characters appear to SHOUT at one another from time to time.One more drawback to this edition of The Return of Dr. Fu Manchu: The characters' dialogue is presented without quotation marks, so the reader has to guess where the dialogue stops and the narration begins. That's not hard to do, just annoying.Could be a fine edition with an active table of contents and a bit more attention to the text. But as things stand now, I prefer the free copy from [...]--which gives due credit to Project Gutenberg, the source of the text. The ManyBooks version has an active table of contents and dialogue that's comes complete with punctuation.
summary: Set-up for Kindle Could Be Improved

reviewText: This is one of the most unusual vampire stories I've ever read. While most stories follow the appearance of a vampire and then proceed to follow them as they cause havoc among dozens of unsuspecting humans, this story takes a sharp turn to the right and goes some place completely unexpected. The story follows Franc, a vampire who is content to lead his life when his ex-lover, Livia, suddenly reappears on-scene and thrusts him into a mad race against time to secure the Scepter of Hades--an item that can return the dead to life. The writing is very good and one gets a really good sense of the character of Franc--his longings, his desire to be loved and his conflicted feeling towards Livia. If you love vampires and want a real vampire tale with heart, check this out!
summary: A vampire's quest for the ultimate power!

reviewText: On the surface this book is quite different from the rest of V.C. Andrews actual books, but once you get past the scifi bits, you see her recurring relationship problems in Sharita and Dray-Gon's interactions. Definitely worth reading.

As an avid reader of V.C. Andrews, I definitely wanted to add this book to my collection. But why would this only be available on Kindle? I for one cannot stand reading books on the computer. Who wants to drag around a lap top when a paperback would be just fine. Unfortunately, since I do not own a Kindle nor will be buying one, I had to download the written copy of this book and put it in a binder to read. Pain in the rear! It's like 600 pages. Whoever thought that e-books are better than paperbacks need to re-consider and PUBLISH this book in a written format.As for the story itself, its a great read once you get past all the science fiction. If you dont really like science fiction, I doubt you'll like it. Its interesting to see a different style of story from Andrews (even though her characters remain familiar) and to think that this was written before Flowers.

reviewText: Enjoyed this book tremendously. Have read all of VC Andrews books.This book being Sci Fiction was something special. The deep thinking was thought provoking. Many questions about our world are still running around in my head since finishing it.This one was completely different. Loved it.

If you've read V.C. Andrews' other books (Flowers in the Attic, My Sweet Audrina, etc) and expect the same here, do not. This is a science-fiction book instead of a Family Gothic saga.That said, this is a good book. It's just different - you can see that V.C. Andrews wanted to try something different - but it is still a good book. I enjoyed it. I do not feel that this represents her best work, hence 4 stars. I would give this book 4.25 stars actually, but unfortunately, Amazon does not allow me to give out star fractions.The story itself is interesting, and has some of the elements of a 'classic' VCA novel - a romance, a story that moves through generations, and a shocking secret/revelation. Now, if this book was available in print, I would be really giddy, as reading it once on a screen was enough for me, a print book would enable me to relax and read it over and over like I do my other VCA books.
Very good book one of VC Andrews top in my opion Although say she never wanted it published I think they made right decision I think she knew this
I would recommend this book for VC Andrews readers. It is a little different than her following novels but I still enjoyed it
i believe this book can only be read on kindle no paper back that is the only way which is fine no more once i start it

This is my secin purchase of this life changing book.  The first was in print.  I think I reviewed this book then too.Molly writes in word pictures.  One can see, feel the breeze, smell the air of what she writes.  I have never read a "spiritual" writer that I understand more.  She is not talking about religion, but God with us in the ordinary and the mysteries of our faith, through the good days and not so good ones.Molly Wolf is a writer that is still on her journey.  She invites us to walk it with her.
I just didn't like his approach. Seems to be working out his personal issues on my time. Verbose. Easy to skip whole sections and not miss much.

I haven't finished this book yet but I have learned so much already!  The transformational exercises are described in such clear, easy to understand language. You can feel Harvey's passion and sincerity in his writing. If you want to add more tools  to your spiritual tool box, this is the book to read!

Not a chronological review of Crenshaw's life, but rather a look at the key moments.Crenshaw's early life in Texas, his relationship with Harvey Penick, his US Masters victories and the 1999 Ryder Cup are all covered. He comes across as someone very respectful of the traditions of the game, and grateful for what he has achieved.However, it possibly gets a little petty when discussing the 1999 Ryder Cup. Apart from the infamous celebrations following Justin Leonard's putt, Crenshaw gives the impression the US team were angels, and everything else (from slow play to rowdy fans) was the fault of the European team. As an Australian I don't care who was at fault, I just want the issue discussed in a straightforward way. The claim and counter claim from Crenshaw and Mark James is like listening to a couple of kids.Apart from that, the book is a good read.
Very inspiring, it helped me a lot. Highly recommended. I started to do more strength training and subscribed for self-defence course.

It's got to be said somewhere and it might as well be here: Kindle does not handle poetry well. Verse is often set as prose, as in the Kindle stand-alone sonnets of Shakespeare. This edition is much better in that respect, but whenever a verse line is too long to fit on one line, it is set as two lines, both with flush left margins (not the usual practice with verse) or even worse, as three lines, all with flush left margins but the last two very short, one or two words apiece. This is hard to read and unnecessary, an obvious computer glitch. On top of that, the prose passages in this volume, and that includes the very important Falstaff scenes, are set in sets of two alternating lines, one normal length, the other quite short, another obvious computer glitch. ALL KINDLE VERSE BOOKS I'VE SEEN SO FAR HAVE SOME OR ALL OF THESE FAILINGS. The problem is systemic: Kindle can't handle verse yet. The rule would seem to be, don't buy poets on Kindle.
a must read for anyone who would like to have good relationships - her stories are easy to relate to
Got a lot out of this book, spoke to my heart in many areas of my life.  Very helpful to assist in moving through issues in my personal life and assist in my growth.
